title: Mereotopology
text:
In <a href="formal%20ontology">formal ontology</a>, a branch of <a href="metaphysics">metaphysics</a>, and in <a href="ontology%20%28computer%20science%29">ontological computer science</a>, mereotopology is a <a href="first-order%20theory">first-order theory</a>, embodying <a href="mereology">mereological</a> and <a href="topological">topological</a> concepts, of the relations among wholes, parts, parts of parts, and the <a href="boundary%20%28topology%29">boundaries</a> between parts.
History and motivation.
Mereotopology begins in philosophy with theories articulated by <a href="A.%20N.%20Whitehead">A. N. Whitehead</a> in several books and articles he published between 1916 and 1929, drawing in part on the mereogeometry of De Laguna (1922). The first to have proposed the idea of a point-free definition of the concept of topological space in mathematics was <a href="Karl%20Menger">Karl Menger</a> in his book "Dimensionstheorie" (1928) -- see also his (1940). The early historical background of mereotopology is documented in Bélanger and Marquis (2013) and Whitehead's early work is discussed in Kneebone (1963: ch. 13.5) and Simons (1987: 2.9.1). The theory of Whitehead's 1929 "<a href="Process%20and%20Reality">Process and Reality</a>" augmented the part-whole relation with topological notions such as <a href="contact%20%28mathematics%29">contiguity</a> and <a href="connected%20space">connection</a>. Despite Whitehead's acumen as a mathematician, his theories were insufficiently formal, even flawed. By showing how Whitehead's theories could be fully formalized and repaired, Clarke (1981, 1985) founded contemporary mereotopology. The theories of Clarke and Whitehead are discussed in Simons (1987: 2.10.2), and Lucas (2000: ch. 10). The entry <a href="Whitehead%27s%20point-free%20geometry">Whitehead's point-free geometry</a> includes two contemporary treatments of Whitehead's theories, due to Giangiacomo Gerla, each different from the theory set out in the next section.
Although mereotopology is a mathematical theory, we owe its subsequent development to <a href="logic">logic</a>ians and theoretical <a href="computer%20science">computer scientists</a>. Lucas (2000: ch. 10) and Casati and Varzi (1999: ch. 4,5) are introductions to mereotopology that can be read by anyone having done a course in <a href="first-order%20logic">first-order logic</a>. More advanced treatments of mereotopology include Cohn and Varzi (2003) and, for the mathematically sophisticated, Roeper (1997). For a mathematical treatment of <a href="point-free%20geometry">point-free geometry</a>, see Gerla (1995). <a href="lattice%20%28order%29">Lattice</a>-theoretic (<a href="algebraic%20structure">algebraic</a>) treatments of mereotopology as <a href="contact%20algebra">contact algebra</a>s have been applied to separate the <a href="topology">topological</a> from the <a href="mereology">mereological</a> structure, see Stell (2000), Düntsch and Winter (2004).
Applications.
<a href="Barry%20Smith%20%28ontologist%29">Barry Smith</a>, Anthony Cohn, <a href="Achille%20Varzi%20%28philosopher%29">Achille Varzi</a> and their co-authors have shown that mereotopology can be useful in <a href="formal%20ontology">formal ontology</a> and <a href="ontology%20%28computer%20science%29">computer science</a>, by allowing the formalization of relations such as <a href="contact%20%28mathematics%29">contact</a>, <a href="connected%20space">connection</a>, <a href="boundary%20%28topology%29">boundaries</a>, <a href="interior%20%28topology%29">interior</a>s, holes, and so on. Mereotopology has been applied also as a tool for qualitative <a href="spatial-temporal%20reasoning">spatial-temporal reasoning</a>, with constraint calculi such as the <a href="Region%20Connection%20Calculus">Region Connection Calculus</a> (RCC). It provides the starting point for the theory of fiat boundaries developed by Smith and Varzi, which grew out of the attempt to distinguish formally between 
Mereotopology is being applied by Salustri in the domain of digital manufacturing (Salustri, 2002) and by Smith and Varzi to the formalization of basic notions of ecology and environmental biology (Smith and Varzi, 1999, 2002). It has been applied also to deal with vague boundaries in geography (Smith and Mark, 2003), and in the study of vagueness and granularity (Smith and Brogaard, 2002, Bittner and Smith, 2001, 2001a).
Preferred approach of Casati & Varzi.
Casati and Varzi (1999: ch.4) set out a variety of mereotopological theories in a consistent notation. This section sets out several nested theories that culminate in their preferred theory GEMTC, and follows their exposition closely. The mereological part of GEMTC is the conventional theory <a href="mereology">GEM</a>. Casati and Varzi do not say if the <a href="model%20theory">models</a> of GEMTC include any conventional <a href="topological%20space">topological space</a>s.
We begin with some <a href="domain%20of%20discourse">domain of discourse</a>, whose elements are called <a href="individual">individual</a>s (a <a href="synonym">synonym</a> for <a href="mereology">mereology</a> is "the calculus of individuals"). Casati and Varzi prefer limiting the ontology to physical objects, but others freely employ mereotopology to reason about geometric figures and events, and to solve problems posed by research in <a href="machine%20intelligence">machine intelligence</a>.
An upper case Latin letter denotes both a <a href="relation%20%28mathematics%29">relation</a> and the <a href="Predicate%20%28mathematical%20logic%29">predicate</a> letter referring to that relation in <a href="first-order%20logic">first-order logic</a>. Lower case letters from the end of the alphabet denote variables ranging over the domain; letters from the start of the alphabet are names of arbitrary individuals. If a formula begins with an <a href="atomic%20formula">atomic formula</a> followed by the <a href="biconditional">biconditional</a>, the subformula to the right of the biconditional is a definition of the atomic formula, whose variables are <a href="bound%20variable">unbound</a>. Otherwise, variables not explicitly quantified are tacitly <a href="universal%20quantifier">universally quantified</a>. The axiom Cn below corresponds to axiom C.n in Casati and Varzi (1999: ch. 4).

If this were not the case, <a href="topology">topology</a> would merely be a model of <a href="mereology">mereology</a> (in which "overlap" is always either primitive or defined).
Ground mereotopology (MT) is the theory consisting of primitive "C" and "P", defined "E" and "O", the axioms C1-3, and axioms assuring that "P" is a <a href="partial%20order">partial order</a>. Replacing the M in MT with the standard <a href="axiom%20of%20extension">extensional</a> mereology <a href="mereology">GEM</a> results in the theory GEMT.

Hence the <a href="Duality%20%28mathematics%29">dual</a> of i, the topological <a href="closure%20operator">closure operator</a> c, can be defined in terms of i, and <a href="Kuratowski">Kuratowski</a>'s axioms for c are theorems. Adding C5-7 to GEMT results in Casati and Varzi's preferred mereotopological theory, GEMTC.

Given some mereotopology X, adding C8 to X results in what Casati and Varzi call the "Whiteheadian extension" of X, denoted WX. Hence the theory whose axioms are C1-8 is WGEMTC.
The converse of C8 is a GEMTC theorem. Hence given the axioms of GEMTC, "C" is a defined predicate if "O" and "SC" are taken as primitive predicates.
